column4: VirtualBlackness:jazzkovsky:I guess?  It's whatever the default is.
what did you do that casued this change?
what desktop?
sudo service lightdm stop    for unity for example
sudo dpkg --configure -a
http://pastebin.com/d9ZjMcBr
this is typically because of a PPA... does ls /etc/apt/sources.list.d produce a result?
google-chrome.list  google-chrome.list.save  local-repository.list  local-repository.list.save
for the time being, please move the contents of that folder somewhere else, and run apt-get update
then please run dpkg --configure -a again, and follow with apt-get -f install
sorry, run both as sudo
ok... I see what is happening
you have an amd64 install of a package and something wants the i386 version...
what you SHOULD do, is move the files back to /etc/apt/sources.list.d and then...
sudo apt-get remove libssl and see the things it will take away with it before agreeing
to use the dpkg force remove we need a HUGE list of depends to ignore... he is trying to spare you that. Ignore it for now
for the record... the praise goes to muelli... I was gonna walk you through a dangerous and painful fix.
at some point you added a (wrong) chrome ppa...
what do I do now that I have ppa-purge installed?
what do I do with this ppa-purge thingy?
I don't actually know... I don't use ppas and I gave you the bot link... lol.
